facts.text: Habeas Corpus Petition No. 15 of 1963 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION .Habeas Corpus Petition No. 15 of 1963. Hebeas Corpus Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: President issued Proclamation declaring Emergency under Art. 352 on October 26, 1962 due to Chinese aggression.

anchor.surface_text: On October 26, 1962, the President having been satisfied that a grave national emergency exists. whereby the security of India or any part of the territory thereof is threatened by the Chinese aggression, issued a Proclamation declaring the Emergency, under Art. 352 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Emergency proclamation laid before Parliament on November 8, 1962, approved by Rajya Sabha on November 13, 1962, and Lok Sabha on November 14, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: That declaration of emergency was laid before both Houses of Parliament on November 8,1962, and was approved by the Rajya Sabha on November 13, 1962, and by the Lok Sabha on November 14, 1962.

facts.text: President promulgated Defence of India Ordinance IV of 1962 on October 26, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: After the Proclamation of Emergency, as Parliament was number in session, and as the President was satisfied that circumstances existed which rendered it necessary for him to take immediate action for exercise of the powers companyferred by cl.  1.  of Art. 123 of the Constitution, he promulgated the Defence of India Ordinance  IV of 1962  on the same date-Octobcr 26, 1962.

facts.text: Central Government promulgated Defence of India Rules, 1962 by notification on November 5, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of those powers, the Central Government promulgated the Defence of India Rules, 1962, by numberification in the Official Gazette, Extraordinary dated November 5, 1962.

facts.text: Rule 30 of Defence of India Rules empowers detention if satisfied person acting prejudicial to defence etc.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of r. 30 is as follows The Central Government or the State Govern- ment, if it is satisfied with respect to any particular person that with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the defence of India and civil de fence, the public safety, the maintenance of public order, Indias relations with foreign powers, the maintenance of peaceful companyditions in any part of India or the efficient companyduct of military operations, it is necessary so to do, may make an order- x x x  b  directing that he be detained x x x

facts.text: President issued Order on November 3, 1962 suspending right to move court for Arts. 21 and 22 during Emergency if deprived under Defence of India Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: During the operation of the Proclamation of Emergency the, President issued, on November 3, 1962, the following Order suspending the right to move any Court for the enforcement of rights companyferred by Arts. 21 and 22 of the Constitution In exercise of the powers companyferred by clause  1  of article 359 of the Constitution, the President hereby declares that right of any person to move any companyrt for the enforcement of the rights companyferred by article 21 and article 22 of the Constitution shall remain snspended for the peried during which the Proclamation of Emergency issued under clause  1  of article 352 thereof on the 26th October 1962, is in force, if such person has been deprived of any such rights under the Defence of India Ordinance, 1962  4 of 1962  or any rule or order made thereunder.

facts.text: Chief Commissioner of Tripura issued detention order against Shri Bipul alias Mohan Chaudhri on November 20, 1962 under Rule 30.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power companyferred by r. 30 aforesaid of the Defence of India Rules, the Chief Commissioner of Tripura issued an order of detention in respect of the petitioner on November 20, 1962 No. F. 22  59 -PD/62 TRIPURA ADMINISTRATION OFFICE OF THE CHIEF COMMISSIONER. Agartala, November 20, 1962. ORDER WHEREAS, 1 am satisfied that Shri Bipul alias Mohan Chaudhri S o Sri Bimala Charan Chaudhri of Sutarmura P. S. Bisalgar should be detained with a view to preventing him her from acting in any manner prejudicial to the defence of India and Civil defence, public safety, the maintenance of public order, Indias relations with foreign powers and the maintenance of peaceful companyditions in Tripura.

facts.text: Petitioner transferred from Agartala Central jail to Hazaribagh Central jail by order dated December 3, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: By a subsequent order dated December 3, 1962, of the Chief Commissioner Tripura, the petitioner was transferred from Agartala Central jail to Hazaribagh Central jail. The order is in these terms TRIPURA ADMINISTRATION HOME DEPARTMENT No.-F. 22  59 -PD/62. Agartala, December 3, 1962. Agrayahana 12, 1884, ORDER In exercise of the powers companyferred by sub-rule  5  of Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules, 1962 read with sub- rule  11  of Rule 2 of the said Rules and all other powers enabling in that behalf, I hereby direct that detenue Shri Bipul Chaudhury alias Mohan son of L. Bimala Charan Chaudhury of Sutarmura, Bishalgarh P. S. be transferred from Agartala Central jail to Hazaribagh Central jail, Bihar for detention in that jail, until further orders.

facts.text: Petitioner filed Habeas Corpus petition under Art. 32 on November 30, 1962 from Agartala jail.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the Petitioner had made a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution for a writ of Habeas Corpus against his detention, as aforesaid. This petition is dated November 30. 1962, while the petitioner was still in the Agartala Central jail.

facts.text: Petitioner sent petition from Hazaribagh jail dated December 15/18, 1962 for contempt against Chief Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, the petitioner sent a petition from the Hazaribagh Central jail in Bihar, dated December 15, 1962/ December 18, 1962 for initiating proceedings for companytempt of Court against the Chief Commissioner, the Union Territory of Tripura.

facts.text: Court directed issue of notice on contempt petition on January 28, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: When this petition was put up before this Court on January 28, 1963, this Court directed the issue of numberice to the opposite party.

facts.text: Shri S.C Mazumdar filed affidavit tendering unconditional apology for withholding petition.

anchor.surface_text: In obedience to the numberice Shri S.C Mazumdar, judicial Secretary, Union Territory of Tripura, made an affidavit to the effect that he had attended to the matter which was the subject of the numberice and that he had number the slightest intention to disregard or disobey the authority of this Court. He further tendered, on his own behalf and on behalf of the Chief Commissioner, Tripura, an unconditional apology.

facts.text: Court accepted apology on February 18, 1963 and directed posting of Habeas Corpus petition.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter was placed before this Court, the Division Bench, by its order dated February 18, 1963, accepted the uncondi- tional apology on behalf of Mr. S. C. Mazumdar and further directed that the Habeas Corpus petition be posted for preliminary hearing.

facts.text: Constitution Bench issued Rule on March 27, 1963 and directed hearing within 10 days.

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution Bench thereafter, by its order dated March 27, 1963, directed the issue of Rule, and hearing of the case within 10 days.

facts.text: Petitioner detained in Delhi jail till disposal of writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: As the petitioner had appeared at the hearing, it was further directed that he be detained in Delhi jail till the disposal of the writ petition.

facts.text: Intervention allowed for Shri Raj Kumar Vohra detained by District Magistrate, Saharanpur.

anchor.surface_text: There was an intervention petition on behalf of one Shri Raj Kumar Vohra, detained by District Magistrate, Saharanpur, in a similar writ petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Respondent raised preliminary objection that petition not maintainable due to President's suspension order.

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the respondent has taken the preliminary Objection to the hearing of the writ petition on merits, on the ground that the President having suspended the enforcement of the rights under Arts. 21 -and 22 of the Constitution, by his Order dated November 3, 1962, quoted above in extenso, the petitioner cannot move this Court under Art. 32 to enforce the right claimed by him.

facts.text: Court upheld preliminary objection and dismissed petition without hearing merits.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the preliminary objection is well-founded. We accordingly intimated to the parties that the Court having accepted the validity of the preliminary objection did number propose to hear the merits of the case and that our reasons for companying to that companyclusion will be given later.

facts.text: Defence of India Act LI of 1962 came into force on December 12, 1962, repealing Ordinance IV of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Act came into force on December 12, 1962. By operation of s.48 of this Act, the Ordinances aforesaid have been repealed, but all action taken and all rules made thereunder have been companytinued in operation by introducing the fiction that they shall be deemed to have been made or taken under the Act, which is deemed to have companymenced on October 26, 1962, the date Ordinance 4 was promulgated.

facts.text: Section 48 of Defence of India Act deems actions under Ordinance as under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Alternatively he companytended, that, under s. 8 of the General Clauses Act  X of 1897 , s. 48 of the Act  LI of 1962 , which repeals Ordinances 4 and 6 of 1962 and which saves anything done or any action taken under those Ordinances has to be companystrued in such a way as to companytinue the Detention Order made under r. 30 of the Defence of India Rules, even after the repeal of the Ordinance under which they were promulgated.

arguments.claim: Right to move court under Art.32 guaranteed by Constitution can be suspended as provided therein (cl.4 Art.32, Arts.358,359)

anchor.surface_text: The right to move this Court for the enforcement of the fundamental rights guaranteed under the Constitution is itself a guaranteed right. But cl. (4) of Art. 32 itself provides that the right so guaranteed could be suspended in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: President's Order under Art.359 suspends petitioner's right to move court for Arts.21/22, not the court's power under Art.32; petitioner lacks locus standi

anchor.surface_text: Unquestionably, the Courts power to issue a writ in the nature of habeas corpus has not been touched by the Presidents Order, but the petitioners right to move this Court for a writ of that kind has been suspended by the Order of the President passed under Art. 359 (1).

arguments.claim: Petitioner lacks locus standi to challenge vires of Ordinance/Act/Rules due to suspension order

anchor.surface_text: In order that the Court may investigate the validity of a particular ordinance or act of a legislature, the person moving the Court should have a locus standi. If he has not the locus standi to move the Court, the Court will refuse to entertain his petition questioning the vires of the particular legislation.

arguments.claim: President's Order dated Nov 3, 1962 is an 'instrument' under s.8 General Clauses Act

anchor.surface_text: Is the Presidents Order in question an instrument within the meaning of the section? The General Clauses Act does not define the expression instrument. ... But in the context of the General Clauses Act, it has to be understood as including reference to a formal legal writing like an Order made under a statute or subordinate legislation or any document of a formal character made under constitutional or statutory authority.

arguments.claim: No need for fresh Presidential Order after enactment of Defence of India Act; s.48 and s.8 avoid supererogation

holdings.text: The preliminary objection raised by the respondent is well-founded and the writ petition under Article 32 is not maintainable on merits due to the President's Order under Article 359 suspending enforcement of rights under Articles 21 and 22.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the preliminary objection is well-founded. We accordingly intimated to the parties that the Court having accepted the validity of the preliminary objection did number propose to hear the merits of the case and that our reasons for companying to that companyclusion will be given later.

holdings.reasoning_summary: President's Order under Art. 359(1) suspends right to move court for enforcement of Arts. 21 and 22; Art. 32 right itself suspendable per cl.4; petitioner lacks locus standi.

holdings.text: Article 359 authorises suspension of the right to move the court under Article 32 for enforcement of the specified fundamental rights under Articles 21 and 22.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention is wholly unfounded. Unquestionably, the Courts power to issue a writ in the nature of habeas companypus has number been touched by the Presidents Order, but the petitioners right to move this Court for a writ of that kind has been suspended by the Order of the President passed under Art. 359  1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 32 cl.4 allows suspension as per Constitution; Art. 359 empowers President to suspend right to move court for specified rights; distinguishes court's power from petitioner's right.

holdings.text: Petitioner has no locus standi to challenge the validity of the Ordinance, Act, Rules or detention order due to suspension under President's Order.

anchor.surface_text: In order that the Court may investigate the validity of a particular ordinance or act of a legislature, the person moving the Court should have a locus standi. If he has number the locus standi to move the Court, the Court will refuse to entertain his petition questioning the vires of the particular legislation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suspension deprives petitioner of right to move court; cannot question vires without locus standi; arguing in circle to challenge precondition.

holdings.text: The condition precedent in President's Order ('if such person has been deprived... under the Defence of India Ordinance') is fulfilled post-repeal by operation of s.48 Defence of India Act and s.8 General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: By operation of s.48 of this Act, the Ordinances aforesaid have been repealed, but all action taken and all rules made thereunder have been companytinued in operation by introducing the fiction that they shall be deemed to have been made or taken under the Act, which is deemed to have companymenced on October 26, 1962, the date Ordinance 4 was promulgated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.48 DIA repeals Ordinance but deems prior actions/rules under Act; s.8 GCA construes references in instruments to repealed provisions as to re-enacted ones.

holdings.text: The President's Order dated November 3, 1962 is an 'instrument' within the meaning of Section 8 of the General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: Is the Presidents Order in question an instrument within the meaning of the section? The General Clauses Act does number define the expression instrument. ... But in the companytext of the General Clauses Act, it has to be understood as including reference to a formal legal writing like an Order made under a statute or subordinate legislation or any document of a formal character made under companystitutional or statutory authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Instrument includes formal legal writing like Order under constitutional powers; s.8 applies to construe reference to Ordinance as to Act.

holdings.text: No fresh Presidential Order under Art. 359 required after enactment of Defence of India Act replacing Ordinance; would be supererogation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal fictions in s.48 DIA and s.8 GCA avoid unnecessary repetition; provisions ensure continuity without new order.

holdings.text: Detention order under r.30 Defence of India Rules made under Ordinance continues validly under Defence of India Act post-repeal.

anchor.surface_text: A proper companystruction of the provisions of s.48 of the Act, which has replaced the Ordinances aforesaid, read in the light of the provisions of s.8 of the General Clauses Act leaves numberroom for doubt that the detention order passed against the petitioner was intended to be companytinued even after the repeal of the Ordinances which were incorporated in the Act  LI of 1962 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.48 deems actions taken under Ordinance as under Act; s.8 applies to President's Order as instrument.
